Coral Island is heavily inspired by Stardew Valley. It doesn't revolutionize the genre or add anything new, but as a farm sim, it offers a good experience. However, even though I generally like the game, it still feels incomplete in many aspects, which prevents me from recommending it in its current state.

The Good

-It has a unique identity. Itâ€™s inspired by Javanese culture, which is quite refreshing considering that over 90% of games on the market draw inspiration from the typical Japanese, Chinese, European, or American cultures.

-The Community Center and Museum are well-designed. They consistently give you rewards as you collect items, complete altars, and achieve goals until the town reaches its coveted "S" rating.

-There's sufficient information within the game itself, mainly from the map and the sturdy computer, so I haven't had to constantly exit the game to look for information on a wiki.

-There are plenty of characters to interact with, and what's most interesting is that as your relationship grows, each heart event connects to the others, telling a small  story.

-It needs a bit more polish, but I appreciate the existence of automation machines for farming, ranching, and artisan machines. This allows you to focus on other tasks.

-There are many decorative structures available. Any creative player will really enjoy designing their farms.

-Storage is universal, which is very convenient when crafting.

The Bad

The game is currently unstable. There are frequent reports of game crashes and quite annoying sound bugs.

-The game should had a manual or auto-save option even before the 1.0 release. Having to repeat an entire day's progress, especially after a crash, is very frustrating.

-The "hanging out" activity is terrible. Not only does ignoring it prevent relationship progress, but it also wastes two in-game hours that could be spent on other activities. And it doesn't matter which destination you choose; the character will agree to go anywhere, and you'll just get the generic "the relationship is growing" message.

-In these types of games with large maps, shortcuts or fast travel points that you can unlock early are always appreciated. However, in this game it takes almost the entire first year to access these, by which point you're practically fed up with walking everywhere.

-It makes no sense to have cooking recipes "locked" after a certain heart event with a character or by watching a cooking show, when you can cook manually. With a little common sense, you can deduce simple ingredients (ice cream, fresh salad, grilled fish, etc.) or just check the wiki directly.

-I'd say the vast majority of the skills you get from leveling up your masteries are useless. Instead of a fixed bonus, they give you laughable probabilities (5% chance to critical strike, 5% chance to obtain double item, 1% chance to drop rare resource, etc.). You don't get the feeling that your character is actually skillful, because you're constantly gambling on chances.

- It's not a major issue, but the game needs to implement an indicator for every item shipped/purchased. It's incredibly tedious to have to resort to an external spreadsheet with a checklist of what I've obtained and what I'm missing.

-I feel the underwater farm is poorly implemented: there is very little space to build, the house is tiny and can barely be decorated, the underwater barns are huge and two of them practically take up a third of the space, and except for the auto-petter and the temperature machine, no other equipment can be used underwater.

The Worst

-There is nothing I hate more than developers releasing unfinished content, as it adds little or nothing to the gameplay: a tattoo shop that doesn't do tattoos; children who are basically dolls you can't interact with; cellar space that exists but isn't "available yet"; the underwater house being non-upgradable; ocean crops not being usable in cooking recipes or artisan goods; building relationships with two factions (Giants and Merfolks) but having no festivals or activities with them, etc.

-Maintaining a clean environment and picking up trash is a noble act in real life, but it's a terribly boring chore. I don't understand the developers' vision to make us believe that picking up trash in the game is fun. Want scrap and glass? Pick up trash. Want to catch some nice fish? Oh no, half of what I got is trash. Want to gather resources in the ocean? Pick up trash. Need treasure chests and fossils for the museum? Pick up trash. The townsfolk love their city but constantly throw trash in the ocean. Half the trash is used tires, but there isn't a single vehicle on the town, thinking in this nonsense it's driving me crazy.

-Once you establish your farming plots and crafting machines and have a good cash flow, the game  ends. There is no compelling late-game content that encourages you to keep playing. You end up swimming in millions with nothing interesting to spend it on, except for super expensive outfits purely for "bragging rights."

-Completionists like me will hate this point: the only way to get the "Fashion Guru" achievement, if you didn't get it before August 21, 2025, is to buy the developers' second game, which "rewards" you with an exclusive outfit that is, of course, counted towards the achievement. While no one is forced to do this, I think it's a very dirty move to expect me to spend $5 on another game (which is also incomplete and in Early Access, by the way).

I will be keeping an eye on new updates because the game has a lot of potential and I hope they fix many of those issues and spark my interest in starting a second playthrough.

Coral Island is heavily inspired by Stardew Valley. It doesn't revolutionize the genre or add anything new, but as a farm sim, it offers a good experience. However, even though I generally like the game, it still feels incomplete in many aspects, which prevents me from recommending it in its current state.

The Good

-It has a unique identity. Itâ€™s inspired by Javanese culture, which is quite refreshing considering that over 90% of games on the market draw inspiration from the typical Japanese, Chinese, European, or American cultures.

-The Community Center and Museum are well-designed. They consistently give you rewards as you collect items, complete altars, and achieve goals until the town reaches its coveted "S" rating.

-There's sufficient information within the game itself, mainly from the map and the sturdy computer, so I haven't had to constantly exit the game to look for information on a wiki.

-There are plenty of characters to interact with, and what's most interesting is that as your relationship grows, each heart event connects to the others, telling a small  story.

-It needs a bit more polish, but I appreciate the existence of automation machines for farming, ranching, and artisan machines. This allows you to focus on other tasks.

-There are many decorative structures available. Any creative player will really enjoy designing their farms.

-Storage is universal, which is very convenient when crafting.

The Bad

The game is currently unstable. There are frequent reports of game crashes and quite annoying sound bugs.

-The game should had a manual or auto-save option even before the 1.0 release. Having to repeat an entire day's progress, especially after a crash, is very frustrating.

-The "hanging out" activity is terrible. Not only does ignoring it prevent relationship progress, but it also wastes two in-game hours that could be spent on other activities. And it doesn't matter which destination you choose; the character will agree to go anywhere, and you'll just get the generic "the relationship is growing" message.

-In these types of games with large maps, shortcuts or fast travel points that you can unlock early are always appreciated. However, in this game it takes almost the entire first year to access these, by which point you're practically fed up with walking everywhere.

-It makes no sense to have cooking recipes "locked" after a certain heart event with a character or by watching a cooking show, when you can cook manually. With a little common sense, you can deduce simple ingredients (ice cream, fresh salad, grilled fish, etc.) or just check the wiki directly.

-I'd say the vast majority of the skills you get from leveling up your masteries are useless. Instead of a fixed bonus, they give you laughable probabilities (5% chance to critical strike, 5% chance to obtain double item, 1% chance to drop rare resource, etc.). You don't get the feeling that your character is actually skillful, because you're constantly gambling on chances.

- It's not a major issue, but the game needs to implement an indicator for every item shipped/purchased. It's incredibly tedious to have to resort to an external spreadsheet with a checklist of what I've obtained and what I'm missing.

-I feel the underwater farm is poorly implemented: there is very little space to build, the house is tiny and can barely be decorated, the underwater barns are huge and two of them practically take up a third of the space, and except for the auto-petter and the temperature machine, no other equipment can be used underwater.

The Worst

-There is nothing I hate more than developers releasing unfinished content, as it adds little or nothing to the gameplay: a tattoo shop that doesn't do tattoos; children who are basically dolls you can't interact with; cellar space that exists but isn't "available yet"; the underwater house being non-upgradable; ocean crops not being usable in cooking recipes or artisan goods; building relationships with two factions (Giants and Merfolks) but having no festivals or activities with them, etc.

-Maintaining a clean environment and picking up trash is a noble act in real life, but it's a terribly boring chore. I don't understand the developers' vision to make us believe that picking up trash in the game is fun. Want scrap and glass? Pick up trash. Want to catch some nice fish? Oh no, half of what I got is trash. Want to gather resources in the ocean? Pick up trash. Need treasure chests and fossils for the museum? Pick up trash. The townsfolk love their city but constantly throw trash in the ocean. Half the trash is used tires, but there isn't a single vehicle on the town, thinking in this nonsense it's driving me crazy.

-Once you establish your farming plots and crafting machines and have a good cash flow, the game  ends. There is no compelling late-game content that encourages you to keep playing. You end up swimming in millions with nothing interesting to spend it on, except for super expensive outfits purely for "bragging rights."

-Completionists like me will hate this point: the only way to get the "Fashion Guru" achievement, if you didn't get it before August 21, 2025, is to buy the developers' second game, which "rewards" you with an exclusive outfit that is, of course, counted towards the achievement. While no one is forced to do this, I think it's a very dirty move to expect me to spend $5 on another game (which is also incomplete and in Early Access, by the way).

I will be keeping an eye on new updates because the game has a lot of potential and I hope they fix many of those issues and spark my interest in starting a second playthrough.

TL;DR
Do not buy the game yet if you are looking to play mainly multiplayer. Game is clearly not ready.
